abstracts.cdata!:
The Disaster Risk Management Development
            Policy Loan with a Catastrophe Deferred Drawdown Option
            (CAT-DDO) for the Philippines received a satisfactory
            outcome rating with moderate risk to development outcome.
            Both the Bank and the Borrower received satisfactory ratings
            for their performances respectively. No major restructurings
            took place throughout the lifespan of this project. The
            CAT-DDO was designed to enhance the capacity of the
            Government of the Philippines to manage the impacts of
            natural disasters. The operation addressed three key
            disaster risk management policy areas prioritized in the
            2010 Philippine Disaster Risk Reduction and Management
            (DRRM) Act: (1) strengthen the institutional capacity for
            disaster risk management efforts; (2) mainstream disaster
            risk reduction into development planning; and (3) better
            manage the Government’s fiscal exposure to natural hazard
            impacts. Several lessons were learned from this project
            including the following: (1) for disaster risk management
            (DRM) policy frameworks with multiple action areas across
            different sectors, a dialogue should be initiated with
            various line agencies during project preparation and
            implementation, (2) development policy operations with
            CAT-DDOs can provide an entry point for introducing broader
            concepts for disaster risk financing and insurance, (3) the
            ‘soft trigger’ for disbursement, which is a standard feature
            of the CAT-DDO instrument, needs to be supported by strong
            analytics in order to optimize the timing of drawdowns, (4)
            Department/Ministry of Finance’s role as implementing agency
            for CAT-DDOs can provide the impetus for their deeper
            involvement in the coordination of DRM-related policy
            actions, (5) the implementation of a programmatic technical
            assistance engagement to support the policy areas of the
            CAT-DDO can facilitate substantive policy dialogue and
            effective implementation even after full disbursement of the
            loan, and (6) complementarity between ongoing World Bank
            investment projects and the CAT-DDO can generate mutual
            leverage for achieving development objectives.
